entry.title: Re: Reports to determine sent mails per user in SOST
entry.content:
SAP provides a standard report for this requirement.

Use report RSSOSOSTSTAT (transaction SE38).

This report gives statistics on outbound SAP Office emails and allows you to analyze:

  • Number of sent emails

  • User‑wise (sender) distribution

  • Time‑based selection

  • Status‑based filtering (sent, error, etc.)

It works directly on SOST data and is suitable even when there are millions of records, avoiding the need to export SOST to Excel manually.

You can view detailed selection options by opening the report documentation in SE38.

entry.title: Re: Personas: How to display each employee's picture?
Re: Lob segment Reorganization failure
entry.content: This is a classic SOFFCONT1 LOB reorganization issue. In Oracle, LOB reorg requires at least 2× the LOB size as free space in the tablespace. Additionally, specific Oracle 11.2.0.3 SBP levels have known bugs impacting SOFFCONT1 reorg. Best practices are: Clean up obsolete SAPoffice data first (SAP Note 1634908) Ensure sufficient free space Prefer export/import via BRSPACE or upgrade to a fixed SBP Reorg failures here are usually space or Oracle bug related, not BRTOOLS itself.

entry.title: Re: Migration Monitor exits with error code 103
entry.content: This error is typical for very large SOFFCONT1 tables during export. R3load is limited to 256 data files per package. SAP Note 1922094 explains this clearly. Splitting the table into smaller packages or using the latest kernel/R3load version is the correct approach.

entry.title: Re: Content server - using RSIRPIRL - how to find PHIO cl...
entry.content:
In short: RSIRPIRL works at PHIO class level, not document type level.

  • SOFFCONT1 documents → PHIO class SOFFPHIO, source category SOFFDB

  • BDS_CONT1 documents → PHIO classes starting with BDS_* (e.g. BDS_DOC, BDS_IMAGE depending on usage)

Key concepts:

  • Repository (OAC0): Physical storage (Content Server)

  • Category (OACT): Logical routing to a repository

  • PHIO Class: Technical document handler (used by RSIRPIRL)

  • Document Type (OAC3): Only relevant for ArchiveLink, not for RSIRPIRL

SKPR08 is relevant only when you want new documents of a PHIO class to be stored in a specific category going forward.
It is not mandatory for RSIRPIRL migration itself.

RSIRPIRL cannot split documents by business document type (e.g. invoice vs PO).
Migration happens per PHIO class only.

For sizing, SOFFCONT1 and BDS_CONT1 table sizes (DB02 / HANA Studio) are the only reliable indicators before migration.

entry.title: Re: Content Repository Migration in mind ?
entry.content: Thanks for sharing this detailed overview of Content Repository Migration approaches. This post clearly explains when to use RSIRPIRL, Z_DOC_COPY, and Z_MIGRATE_ARCHIVELINK based on the application context (GOS, DMS, ArchiveLink, KPro). Very helpful for avoiding common mistakes like using a generic report for application‑specific attachments. This will definitely help during planning and sizing for large‑scale migrations.

entry.title: Bulk upsert in SAP HANA
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm using mulesoft to perform bulk upsert in SAP HANA from a source table that has duplicate values, usually I expect to get a return of an array [1,1,1,1,...] but Im getting  [1,1,2,2,3,3,1,1,...]. Does anyone knows what 2 and 3 means?

entry.title: Re: Equipment :- Program logic to fetch Internal note and attachment from Equipment
entry.content: Thanks for the clarification. This helps a lot in understanding the difference between Equipment internal notes (stored in STXH/STXL via READ_TEXT) and attachments added via GOS/Services for Object (linked through SRGBTBREL and SAP Office tables like SOFFCONT1). This gives a clear direction for handling both in the workflow logic.

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
Hello @joe_jones2 ,

If you don't generate W-2 PR on your system, you don't need to apply the Phase II Note for now.
This will be required if the note is set as a pre-requisite for another note, or the delivery will be on your system once you apply the corresponding support package.

Thank you,
Carlos

entry.title: Re: Document display from fb03 not possible
entry.content: This issue occurs because SOFFCONT1 was excluded during client copy, so the attachment content is missing. SOFFPHIO/SOFFOIO may exist, but without SOFFCONT1 the documents cannot be displayed. Transport is not recommended for a 50 GB table—please restore SOFFCONT1 from backup or re-copy it using a system copy / export–import method.

entry.title: Re: User exit for adding text in PO History
entry.content: MO

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
Hello @juli_thompson and @ConeC ,

SAP is closely monitoring with the Authority the reporting of Washington Cares in W-2 Box 14.
Do you have the Authority publication saying that this is required? So, I can share with SAP Product Management team for validation.

Thank you,
Carlos

entry.title: Re: how to retrieve data from content repository
entry.content:
When documents are relocated from SOFFCONT1 to an external Content Repository using RSIRPIRL, they are no longer accessed via ArchiveLink transactions (OAAD / OAOR).

These documents are SAPoffice / KPro documents, so they must be accessed through the original business object or SAPoffice, not directly from the repository.

Key points:

  • RSIRPIRL moves content physically and updates KPro metadata.

  • After relocation, SOFFCONT1 is empty, but metadata remains in:

    • SOFFPHIO

    • SOFFLOIO

    • SOC3 / SOOD

  • Verify that the storage category in SOFFPHIO has changed from SOFFDB to your target category.

  • End users can retrieve the documents only via the original transaction/object (e.g. GOS, attachment list), not via OAAD/OAOR.

  • OAAD/OAOR are relevant for ArchiveLink, not SAPoffice/KPro documents.

So, if the application linkage is intact, document access will continue transparently after relocation.

entry.title: Re: How to interpret SAP HANA DB table sizes definitions?
entry.content:
Explanation of DB02 table size metrics:

  • Estimated maximum memory consumption: Expected RAM usage when the table is fully loaded into memory (compressed, column-store).

  • Current memory consumption – Main storage: Memory used by the main (merged, read-optimized) column store.

  • Current memory consumption – Delta storage: Memory used by unmerged delta records (new/changed data).

  • Current total memory consumption: Main + Delta memory usage.

  • Size on disk: Physical persistence on disk (usually larger due to LOBs, history, and storage format).

Large differences (e.g., SOFFCONT1) are normal because LOB data is usually not fully loaded into memory.

entry.title: Re: Retreival of the Archived BCS (Buiness Communication...
entry.content:
There is no SAP‑standard or SAP‑supported procedure to restore archived BCS (SOFFCONT1) data from the SAP Content Server back into the SAP database.

Reports like RSIRPIRL are designed as a one‑way relocation from database to content repository to reduce DB growth. SAP does not provide any reverse report to reload content into SOFFCONT1.

Access to archived BCS data is expected to remain via the Content Server / SAPoffice framework, not by reinserting records into SOFFCONT1. Any attempt to bring data back would require custom development and is not recommended or supported by SAP, especially in S/4HANA due to HANA cost and data consistency risks.

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
Hello @ChandraV,

The main delivery of note 3695859 (TAX: Technology and Customer Service Fee tax for Ohio) was to add the concept of UI Continuity for Ohio Tax Type 78, as per the Authority guideline.
In case your business is subject to Ohio Unemployment Surcharge Tax, Tax Type 78 needs to be added on your Tax Model.

Best Regards,
Carlos

entry.title: Re: Table to fetch the Title & the Address of the URL
entry.content:
For GOS “Create external document (URL)”, the Title is stored in SOOD.
The URL/address itself is stored in table SOC3 (field depending on SAP release), not in SOFFCONT1.
URLs and notes are handled as SAPoffice documents; only PC attachments may go to SOFFCONT1/KPro.
Refer to SAP Note 530792 for the exact storage behavior.

entry.title: Re: SOC3 and SOFFCOUNT1 Archiving
entry.content:
SOC3 data can be archived using standard SAP tools such as report RSSOAPUT (BCS archiving).
However, SOFFCONT1 does not support archiving via SAP Archive Development Kit. Entries can only be deleted/reorganized (for example using RSBCS_REORG or by relocating content to a content server via RSIRPIRL).
Always test thoroughly before executing in production.

entry.title: Re: Find were the actual attachment is stored in table.
entry.content:
SOC3 data can be archived using report RSSOAPUT (after proper testing).
SOFFCONT1 cannot be archived via SAP archiving objects; it can only be deleted/reorganized using RSBCS_REORG or relocated to a content server using RSIRPIRL.
SAP does not provide a standard archive object for SOFFCONT1.

entry.title: Re: Moivng contents of SOC3 table to Content server
entry.content:
SOC3 data cannot be migrated to a Content Server in the same way as SOFFCONT1.

SOFFCONT1 stores large binary content managed via KPro and can be relocated to a Content Server using RSIRPIRL.

SOC3 mainly contains small contents such as notes, URLs, and metadata, and is not designed for KPro-based content server relocation. SAP does not provide any standard tool or procedure to move SOC3 content to a Content Server.

The supported approach for SOC3 is SAP Office archiving/deletion, for example using report RSSOAPUT, after proper testing.

If SOC3 is growing significantly, review usage patterns and housekeeping rather than content server migration.

entry.title: Re: Regarding the SAP big tables in ECC 6.0
entry.content:
These are standard SAP tables that typically grow over time.
• TST03 – Spool data; clean up using RSPO0041 / RSPO1041 and reorganize if oversized.
• COEP – CO line items; reduce size via CO archiving objects in SARA.
• SOFFCONT1 – SAP Office document content; reduce via reorganization/relocation (e.g. RSIRPIRL) and deletion policies.
• GLPCA – PCA line items; archive using EC-PCA archiving objects.
• EDI40 – IDoc data; delete/archive old IDocs (WE11 / SAP Note 40088).
Refer to the SAP Database Management Guide and relevant SAP Notes for prevention and cleanup.

entry.title: Re: After import table content is missing
entry.content: This is the correct approach for recovering SOFFCONT1 after an incomplete Unicode migration. Using R3load -merge_bck preserves newly created data and avoids overwriting active records. Important to validate dependencies and test carefully before production use.

entry.title: Re: Most allocated extents in any segment oracle 11g
entry.content:
For Oracle 11g with locally managed tablespaces, a high number of extents (even for LOB segments like SOFFCONT1) is not an issue because MAX_EXTENTS is UNLIMITED and extent sizes are managed automatically.
This CCMS alert is informational only. No action is required unless you see real space or performance problems.
Refer SAP Note 483856 for details.

entry.title: Re: How the project attachment file link to project?
entry.content:
In CJ20N, project attachments are linked via Generic Object Services (GOS) / BDS.
The relationship between the project (object type BUS2054 / PROJ) and attachments is stored in SRGBTBREL.
For SAPoffice attachments, document data is held in SOOD / SOFM / SOC3 / SOFFCONT1.

To retrieve attachments programmatically, use BDS_ALL_CONNECTIONS_GET (for BDS/ArchiveLink) or GOS APIs.
SAP Note 530792 explains the storage and linkage in detail.

entry.title: Re: Unknown objects in ABAP Dictionary
entry.content:
The unknown object SOFFCONT1#$ is a leftover from an interrupted BRSPACE table reorganization. It can be safely removed using:
brspace -f tbreorg -t SOFFCONT1#$ -a cleanup.

The SAP_AUXSTATS DB view belongs to DBA Cockpit/Oracle statistics and may appear as “unknown” in older Basis releases. No manual action is recommended—open an SAP incident if the warning persists.

entry.title: Re: Content Server Table for REBDPR Tcode
entry.content: Attachments in REBDPR are handled via SAPoffice. SOFFLOIO / SOFFPHIO store the logical & physical document references, while the actual content is stored in SOFFCONT1 (or an external content server if configured). See SAP Note 904711 for full details. SQL/ABAP trace during upload can confirm the flow.

entry.title: Re: Reduce size LOBSEGMENT
entry.content: Deleting entries from SOFFCONT1 does not automatically shrink the associated LOB segment. For LOBs, space is not released unless the LOB is moved or rebuilt. You need to reorganize the LOB segment explicitly (e.g. BRSPACE LOB reorg or MOVE LOB), or relocate content to a content server (RSIRPIRL). Otherwise, the LOB size remaining large is expected behavior.

entry.title: Re: what is the procedure to transfer attached documents...
entry.content:
There is no supported way to transfer attachments by transporting SOFFCONT1. Attachments are part of SAPoffice/KPro and must be moved using standard relocation tools.

If attachments are stored in the database, use RSIRPIRL to relocate them to a Content Server. If they are already on a Content Server, configure the new repository (OAC0/OACT/SKPR08) and perform a content server migration using SAP‑supported tools (repository copy or vendor tools like OpenText).

Transporting SOFFCONT1 is not recommended and can lead to inconsistencies.

entry.title: Re: Content Repository Migration in mind ? Part IV Error in Migration
entry.content: Thanks for the detailed explanation. For Content Repository migration errors, checking SLG1 logs (objects SDOK and SCMS) is crucial to identify whether the issue is at the source or target repository. Verifying the target repository with RSCMST / RSCMSTH0 before reruns also helps avoid partial or inconsistent migrations. This blog is very helpful for troubleshooting RSIRPIRL-related issues.

entry.title: Re: systemVars.dimensions.viewport.height malfunction
entry.content: Apparently, this issue appears on some devices e.g. on Android 16, while older devices, e.g. Android 11 work properly!

entry.title: Re: Archiving Emails in CRM
entry.content: Email archiving in CRM is not done via WORKITEM archiving alone. Attachments are stored in SOFFCONT1 and should be relocated using RSIRPIRL to a content server. Email body/text stored in SOC3 / SAPoffice can be archived via SOY8. WORKITEM archiving is only relevant if emails are processed via SAP Connect workflow. SAP Note 904711 gives a good overview.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic table name in Select * From (Table_name)
entry.content:
you can select the data but that won't help you at all,
because there is no dynamic data target.

entry.title: Re: Row Compression in db2 9.7
entry.content: TST03 growth is mainly driven by LOB data, so DB2 row compression has limited effect. Best approach is housekeeping as per SAP Note 48400 or increasing INLINE LENGTH for the LOB. For SOFFCONT1, moving content to an external repository is recommended.

entry.title: TMS External Planning via CPI
entry.content:
There are many situations where a TMS application must connect with external or 3rd‑party systems such as JDE, MercuryGate, or legacy home‑grown applications. These integrations are typically implemented to exchange transportation data, automate business transactions, and maintain end-to-end visibility across the supply chain.

 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e3dc5400c1cc41d1bc0ae0e7fd9aa5a2/5505d7ffe42c496788d504e54ce80e59.html?locale=en-US

In a typical SAP TM landscape, standard SAP integration enables the system to send Freight Units (FUs) to an external or 3rd‑party Transportation Management application (such as JDE, MercuryGate, or a legacy system) without requiring any custom development.

The standard process works as follows:

  1. SAP TM creates Freight Units (FUs) based on sales orders, purchase orders, or deliveries.
  2. These FUs are sent to the 3rd‑party TMS using SAP’s out‑of‑the‑box integration capabilities ( CPI,).
  3. The external TMS performs:
    • Load planning
    • Carrier selection
    • Routing
    • Tendering
  4. The 3rd‑party system then sends routing and carrier assignment confirmation back to SAP TM using the standard interface.
  5. SAP TM automatically:
    • Creates a Freight Order (FO) based on the received planning data
    • Links the FO to the original Freight Unit
    • Consumes the FU (i.e., the FU becomes assigned to the FO)

All of this is supported by SAP’s standard integration content, which means no custom development is required for core message flows or planning confirmation processing.

Configuration Steps : 

1. Enable the PPF action : TOR_TPNOR_FU at FU level using 

2. Activate the services in SICF 

3. Check the SRT_ADMIN report for Webservice and Task Watcher readiness (SAP support team help need to run the SRT_ADMIN in 000 client via serivce ticket)

4. Create SOAP endpoint in CPI

5. Expose/obtain the WSDL for that endpoint (from CPI).

6. Create Logical Port in SOAMANAGER for your DEV  unit test client

 How to Test : 

Here’s a clean, step‑by‑step way to Generate a Freight Unit (FU) in SAP TM and verify that the PPF action triggers successfully and XML is generated for outbound integration — exactly what you'd check during FU → 3rd‑party integration testing.

For any errors , please check the tcode SRT_UTIL 

Summary : 

1. S/4 to External Planning system : TransportationOrderGenericRequest_Out

2. External Planning System to S/4 : TransportationOrderGenericRequest_In

If you want to receive charges from the external planning system, you must use the additional web service TransportationOrderChargeElementRequest_In, as charge transfers are not covered by the standard inbound service TransportationOrderGenericRequest_In.

 
Would like to share my findings with SAP community!

Thank you
Hari Sivvala

entry.title: Re: where is the attached file stored in ECC6.0?
entry.content:
In ECC 6.0, attachments (texts, screenshots, files) are typically stored in table SOFFCONT1 (content), with metadata in SOOD / SOFM.
There is no fixed SAP limit, but large attachments increase database size, so SAP recommends moving them to a Content Server

entry.title: Re: Optimizing DMO Process During SAP S/4HANA Conversion

entry.title: Re: We have setup bank account to All currencies. And wan...
entry.content: If you mean house bank accounts, the currency is not defined by the bank account itself, but rather by GL account that is set for this bank. So if you want to change to a single currency, create new GL account with that currency and set this GL account on your bank account.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

entry.title: Re: Using Custom Table API via Web Service (SOAP) after 2...
entry.content: Yes SOAP service will still be supported and it is not affected with announced changes.

entry.title: Re: Statement Level Trigger (SQL Anywhere 17)
entry.content:
To get the clean output, I chained a GREP command to the output of the dbmanageetd  basedon  SYS_Audit_String search pattern. This could also be handled with a regular expression if you do not have a grep tool on the system.

My last suggested delete trigger has a counter in the fetch loop that is used to detect and report a no-op delete statement.  If the counter is 0 after processing the NEW temp table, it means that the delete statement was a no-op.  In that case,, an audit string  "No row impacted by DELETE"  is logged. Note that this will only work with statement level triggers. and  It is really a rough idea of how this could be implemented.

entry.title: Re: what are the SAP inbox tables.
entry.content:
SAP Inbox (SBWP) data is mainly retrieved from workflow and SAPoffice tables.
Key tables include:

  • SWWUSERWI – workflow work items for a specific user (main inbox driver)

  • SWWWIHEAD / SWWWIAGENT – work item header and agent assignment

  • SOC3 – SAPoffice document content (mail/body)

  • SOOD / SOOS – SAPoffice document headers and status

  • SOFFCONT1 – attachments

A large inbox (e.g. 37k entries) usually causes timeout due to SWWUSERWI volume.
Using workflow archiving and inbox cleanup is recommended.

entry.title: Re: Reorganize/Archive SAPOffice documents
entry.content:
Your understanding is largely correct.

  • RSBCS_REORG deletes SAPoffice documents (cleanup, not real archiving).

  • Mass archiving of historical SAPoffice documents (e.g. year-based) is not supported by SAP standard.

  • Documents can be stored in a content repository via storage category configuration, but this applies mainly to newly created documents.

  • For existing documents, realistic options are deletion via RSBCS_REORG / SOY5 / SOY8 or using third‑party tools to move content from SOFFCONT1 to an external repository.

entry.title: Re: TDMS functionality question - Time slice scenario
entry.content:
In TDMS time-based slice scenarios, SAP Office tables (including SOFFCONT1) are not transferred. Attachments stored in SOFFCONT1 are excluded, while DMS tables like DMS_CONT1_CD1 are transferred in full.

By default, TDMS excludes SAP Office, Workflow, Change Docs, Users/Roles, Variants, and similar technical data.
Time-based scenarios transfer full master data + reduced transactional data.
Runtime depends heavily on hardware, parallel jobs, and table sizes—there’s no reliable generic estimate.

entry.title: how to setup resource group in the Joule Agent Builder
entry.content:
Hi,

I am trying create a Joule Agent using Joule Agent Builder in SAP Build Joule Studio. I am trying to add a tool of type document in the agent.

 

When I try to add document, its asking to add resource group in the control tower.  I am not able to understand what should be added as AI core Destination and Object Store destination. Do we have to setup destination which points SAP AI core service and SAP Object Store service instances. I think document can come from Microsoft Share Point or SAP Object Store, is it mandatory to use SAP Object Store? Is it also mandatory to have SAP AI core subscription in order to add documents in the agent in the Joule Agent Builder

entry.title: Re: Table still fragmented after REORG !!
entry.content: Conclusion: PCL2 is not actually fragmented. The high “wasted space” reported by the script from SAP Note 821687 is misleading because the table contains a LOB (BLOB) column. When analyzed with DBMS_SPACE (Note 1295200 / 1438410), fragmentation is minimal and UNUSED_MB is low. REORG was therefore not required

entry.title: Re: Prevent tables from loading into memory
entry.content: You cannot prevent tables from loading into HANA memory. Unload priority only affects when they are unloaded. Best practice is to archive/reorganize workflow and PI tables, and move SOFFCONT1 attachments to an external content repository (per SAP Note 1634908). Dynamic tiering can also be considered for warm data.

entry.title: Re: Database error <>
entry.content:
We faced the same Database error <GET DATA FROM KPRO> issue after upgrade.
Root cause was missing SOFFCONT1 content for old PHIOs due to incomplete data during system copy/upgrade.
Restoring affected documents from backup resolved the issue.
New documents were unaffected.

entry.title: Re: Where SAP store the uploaded files?
entry.content:
Uploaded files are not stored automatically by SAP.
In Web Dynpro, the FileUpload UI element only holds the file temporarily in memory (XSTRING).
The application decides where to store it:

  • SAP Office / KPro → SOFFCONT1 (or Content Server if configured)

  • DMS / GOS / ArchiveLink → external content repository

  • Custom logic → database table or application server (AL11)

Physical storage is explained in SAP Note 904711.

Please note that I'm working with Public Cloud.

Thank you for your support.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA TOOL OF CHOICE FOR MIGRATION (Migration Cockpit)
entry.content:
Thank you for this clear and practical overview of the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit. The step‑by‑step explanation—from object selection and data cleansing to simulation and monitoring—is especially helpful for teams new to S/4HANA Cloud migrations.

I also appreciate the emphasis on migrating clean, open data and respecting object dependencies, which is often underestimated in real projects. This blog is a great self‑enablement guide for customers and consultants preparing for cloud data migration.

entry.title: Re: Preparing for a Digital Transformation: SAP S/4HANA migration steps
entry.content: Thank you for this well-structured overview of the S/4HANA migration journey. The comparison of greenfield, brownfield, and Bluefield approaches and the strong emphasis on preparation, custom code readiness, and data strategy are especially valuable for teams in the early planning phase. A very practical guide for anyone preparing for ECC to S/4HANA transformation.

entry.title: Re: S/4Hana Busines Partner - Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI) Concept between traditional ECC Vs S
entry.content: Very clear and detailed explanation of the BP–CVI concept and its differences between ECC and S/4HANA. The clarification around BP creation and synchronization is especially helpful for migration projects. Thanks for sharing your practical insights.

entry.title: Re: 在SAP系统所有账套共用调整汇率且可为记账汇率，如果维护了汇率后，那后续所有账套新增的账务处理都会用这个调...
entry.content: 感谢您的帮助与支持，谢谢您

entry.title: Re: Can't seem to remove the spacing at the beginning of the report in Crystal Reports
entry.content: Hi! I've had this issue a few times. I have a few questions to help troubleshoot: - If you select/highlight all objects in preview, is there an outline of something in the area outlined in red? - Are group header/footers suppressed? - Could "New page after" be ticked on a section? - Are all keep together checkboxes unticked, including on subreport/object/section? - Are the headers/footers conditionally suppressed?

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Silent Data Migration Infrastructure (Quick Guide)
entry.content: Thanks for the clear overview of SDMI and the real upgrade experience. For anyone looking to go deeper, SAP Note 2842212 and the SDMI quick guide on SAP Training provide helpful technical and functional details around setup, monitoring, and prerequisites.

entry.title: Re: Is Selective Data Transition the Best Fit for Your SA...
entry.content:
There is no single “best” migration approach for all customers.
The right choice between Brownfield, Greenfield, or Selective Data Transition (SDT) depends on business goals, system complexity, data volume, and transformation scope.

  • Brownfield fits customers who want a faster technical conversion with minimal process change.

  • Greenfield is ideal when major process redesign and clean-core adoption are priorities.

  • Selective Data Transition works well when customers need to retain specific historical data and critical processes while still modernizing selectively.

A detailed assessment of data, custom code, timelines, and business readiness is essential before deciding the migration path.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Conversion - t5 - Custom Code Migration step-by-step
entry.content: Thanks for sharing this detailed overview. The comparison between Greenfield, Brownfield, and Selective Data Transition clearly highlights how to choose the right approach based on scope, data, and transformation needs. Very helpful for planning an S/4HANA migration.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA System Conversion
entry.content: Thanks for sharing this detailed overview of S/4HANA system conversion. It gives a clear end‑to‑end picture of technical, functional, and data migration activities. Even though it’s an older post, many fundamentals are still very useful for understanding the conversion approach.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA On-premise vs Cloud
entry.content: Thank you for the clear comparison between SAP S/4HANA On‑Premise and Cloud. The explanation of licensing, upgrade cycles, and suitability for different company sizes is very helpful for decision‑making. It would be great to also see an updated comparison covering the latest S/4HANA releases and a clearer distinction between S/4HANA Cloud Public, Private, and On‑Premise to avoid confusion.

entry.title: Re: Conversion to SAP S/4HANA- Insights into Finance Data Migration
entry.content: “Very insightful overview of finance data migration in S/4HANA. The clear breakdown of phases, tooling, and common pitfalls is especially helpful for planning a smooth conversion.”

entry.title: Re: Conversion to S/4HANA 1809FPS0 - t5 - Custom Code Migration

entry.title: Re: Everything you need to know about MRP Areas in S/4HANA
entry.content: Very informative and well-structured blog. The overview of mandatory MRP Areas in S/4HANA and the newer features (like intra-plant view and mass processing) is especially helpful. Thanks for sharing these practical insights!

entry.title: How to Extend the “By” Search Criteria in Transaction BP (SAP S/4HANA)?
entry.content:
Dear SAP experts,

when accessing transaction BP in SAP S/4HANA, business partners can be searched using the “Find” tab.
Within this tab, the “By” dropdown list provides various search criteria.

How can this dropdown list be extended with additional search options, for example the Business Partner grouping?

Thank you in advance.

Kind regards,
Emal Rahman

entry.title: Re: Display In-Progress Workflows in Compensation Forms during Annual Salary Review
entry.content:
Hi @xavierlegarrec , 

The objective was to provide visibility to planners/HRs regarding the workflows status. I think its upon the business to decide what to do with information provided (whether to skip the exceptional cases or not). 

However, the "Date of Last of Salary Increase" method you mentioned is useful if the business looks to skip such cases. I believe the decision to handle such cases vary from business to business.

Thanks,

Aaditya

entry.title: Getting Unconventional with Groovy - Part 2 - connecting to SAP CI's underlying postgree DB
entry.content:
Introduction:

Before I start this let me share that this article is just for the curious bunch of people. I am not recommending you to connect to postgree db of SAP CI for any productive scenarios.

SAP CI exposes the following credentials / private keys in System Env variable VCAP_SERVICES

Security Credentials Exposed in VCAP_SERVICES

Exposed Credentials and Keys

Database Credentials (PostgreSQL)

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Plain text username and password
  • Full database connection strings with hostname, port, dbname
  • SSL certificates (root CA certificates)
  • Direct access to production database with full CRUD permissions

Certificate-Based Authentication (Multiple Services)

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • X.509 client certificates (full certificate chains)
  • Private RSA keys (PKCS#8 and PEM formats) for:
    • Connectivity service
    • Enterprise messaging
    • Destination service
    • XSUAA (authentication)
    • Kafka
  • These private keys provide identity proof and decrypt capabilities

OAuth2 / XSUAA Tokens

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Client IDs and client secrets
  • Token endpoints and verification keys
  • Service instance IDs
  • Tenant/zone identifiers

Kafka Credentials

  • Risk Level: HIGH
  • Username and password for Kafka authentication
  • Client certificates and private keys
  • Broker endpoints (hostnames and ports)
  • Topic-level permissions mapping

Credential Store Encryption Keys

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Client private keys for encryption
  • Server public keys
  • OAuth credentials for accessing the credential store itself
  • Access policy definitions showing what namespaces can be accessed

Azure Blob Storage

  • Risk Level: HIGH
  • Storage account names
  • SAS (Shared Access Signature) tokens with full container access
  • Container URIs and region information

Dynatrace APM

  • Risk Level: MEDIUM
  • API tokens with environment access
  • Environment IDs
  • API URLs

Connectivity Service

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • On-premise proxy hostnames and ports
  • Certificates and private keys
  • Access to Cloud Connector for hybrid connectivity

As I have maintained this is a security risk and SAP should plug this. Username and Passwords SHOULD NOT be available/visible at all in VCAP_SERVICES file.

anyways..here is a groovy script that finds out all the tables on the postgree sql db, lists them and also lists top 10 rows from each table. 

This is only a read operation and does not modify the db in any way.

 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.sql.Sql;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String);
    DatabaseManager db = null
    
    try {
        def vcapJson = java.lang.System.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
        def vcap = new JsonSlurper().parseText(vcapJson)
        def psql = vcap."postgresql-db"[0].credentials
        
        def psql_username = psql.username
        def psql_password = psql.password
        def psql_hostname = psql.hostname
        def psql_port = psql.port
        def psql_dbname = psql.dbname
        
        db = new DatabaseManager(
            psql_hostname + ":" + psql_port, 
            psql_dbname, 
            psql_username, 
            psql_password
        )
        
        Sql sql = db.getSql();
        def tables = []
        
        // If body is empty, get all tables first
        if (body == null || body.trim().isEmpty()) {
            def tableQuery = """
                SELECT table_name 
                FROM information_schema.tables 
                WHERE table_schema = 'public' 
                AND table_type = 'BASE TABLE'
                ORDER BY table_name
            """
            def tableResults = sql.rows(tableQuery)
            tables = tableResults.collect { it.table_name }
        } else {
            // Parse JSON array from body
            def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()
            def parsed = jsonSlurper.parseText(body)
            
            if (parsed instanceof List) {
                parsed.each { item ->
                    if (item instanceof String) {
                        tables.add(item)
                    } else if (item instanceof Map && item.table_name) {
                        tables.add(item.table_name)
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        
        def output = new StringBuilder()
        output.append("{\n")
        output.append("  \"_meta\": {\"tables_scanned\": ${tables.size()}, \"timestamp\": \"${new Date().format('yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')}\"},\n")
        
        tables.eachWithIndex { tableName, tableIdx ->
            output.append("  \"${tableName}\": {\n")
            
            try {
                // Get row count
                def countResult = sql.firstRow("SELECT COUNT(*) as cnt FROM \"${tableName}\"".toString())
                def rowCount = countResult?.cnt ?: 0
                output.append("    \"total_rows\": ${rowCount},\n")
                
                // Get columns with types
                def colQuery = """
                    SELECT column_name, data_type 
                    FROM information_schema.columns 
                    WHERE table_name = '${tableName}' 
                    ORDER BY ordinal_position
                """.toString()
                def columns = sql.rows(colQuery)
                output.append("    \"columns\": [")
                output.append(columns.collect { "\"${it.column_name}(${it.data_type})\"" }.join(", "))
                output.append("],\n")
                
                // Get top 10 rows
                def rows = sql.rows("SELECT * FROM \"${tableName}\" LIMIT 10".toString())
                output.append("    \"data\": [\n")
                
                rows.eachWithIndex { row, rowIdx ->
                    output.append("      {")
                    def cols = []
                    row.each { key, value ->
                        def valStr = sanitizeValue(value)
                        cols.add("\"${key}\": \"${valStr}\"")
                    }
                    output.append(cols.join(", "))
                    output.append("}")
                    if (rowIdx < rows.size() - 1) output.append(",")
                    output.append("\n")
                }
                
                output.append("    ]\n")
                
            } catch (Exception e) {
                output.append("    \"error\": \"${e.message.replaceAll('"', "'").take(200)}\"\n")
            }
            
            output.append("  }")
            if (tableIdx < tables.size() - 1) output.append(",")
            output.append("\n")
        }
        
        output.append("}")
        message.setBody(output.toString())
        
    } catch (Exception e) {
        message.setBody("ERROR: ${e.message}\n\nStack: ${e.stackTrace.take(10).join('\n')}")
    } finally {
        if (db != null) {
            db.close()
        }
    }
    
    return message;
}

def String sanitizeValue(Object value) {
    if (value == null) return "null"
    
    def str = value.toString()
    
    // Handle binary/byte arrays
    if (value instanceof byte[]) {
        str = "[BINARY: ${value.length} bytes]"
    }
    
    // Truncate, escape quotes and newlines
    str = str.take(500)
        .replaceAll('\\\\', '\\\\\\\\')
        .replaceAll('"', '\\\\"')
        .replaceAll('\n', '\\\\n')
        .replaceAll('\r', '\\\\r')
        .replaceAll('\t', '\\\\t')
    
    return str
}

class DatabaseManager {
    private Sql sql
    private boolean isConnected = false
    
    DatabaseManager(String hostPort, String database, String username, String password) {
        String jdbcUrl = "jdbc:postgresql://${hostPort}/${database}?sslmode=require"
        try {
            this.sql = Sql.newInstance(jdbcUrl, username, password, "org.postgresql.Driver")
            this.isConnected = true
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new RuntimeException("Failed to connect to database: ${e.message}", e)
        }
    }
    
    Sql getSql() {
        if (!isConnected) {
            throw new IllegalStateException("Database connection is closed")
        }
        return sql
    }
    
    void close() {
        if (sql != null && isConnected) {
            sql.close()
            isConnected = false
        }
    }
}

 

But lets not stop here. SAP must have given these creds in plaintext for a reason and maybe we should go ahead and create a table of our own and insert some values as well.

 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.sql.Sql;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String);
    DatabaseManager db = null
    
    try {
        def vcapJson = java.lang.System.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
        def vcap = new JsonSlurper().parseText(vcapJson)
        def psql = vcap."postgresql-db"[0].credentials
        
        def psql_username = psql.username
        def psql_password = psql.password
        def psql_hostname = psql.hostname
        def psql_port = psql.port
        def psql_dbname = psql.dbname
        
        db = new DatabaseManager(
            "${psql_hostname}:${psql_port}", 
            psql_dbname, 
            psql_username, 
            psql_password
        )
        
        Sql sql = db.getSql();
        def output = new StringBuilder()
        
        // Create table
        output.append("=== Creating Table ===\n")
        sql.execute('''
            CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS test_table (
                id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
                name VARCHAR(100),
                created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
            )
        '''.toString())
        output.append("Table 'test_table' created successfully\n\n")
        
        // Insert row
        output.append("=== Inserting Row ===\n")
        def timestamp = new Date().format('yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')
        def insertSQL = 'INSERT INTO test_table (name) VALUES (?) RETURNING id, name, created_at'
        def insertedRow = sql.firstRow(insertSQL, ["Test Entry ${timestamp}".toString()])
        output.append("Inserted row: ID=${insertedRow.id}, Name=${insertedRow.name}, Created=${insertedRow.created_at}\n\n")
        
        // Select and display results
        output.append("=== Selecting All Rows ===\n")
        def selectSQL = 'SELECT * FROM test_table ORDER BY id DESC LIMIT 10'
        def rows = sql.rows(selectSQL)
        
        output.append("Found ${rows.size()} row(s):\n")
        rows.each { row ->
            output.append("  ID: ${row.id} | Name: ${row.name} | Created: ${row.created_at}\n")
        }
        
        message.setBody(output.toString())
        
    } catch (Exception e) {
        message.setBody("ERROR: ${e.message}\n\nStack: ${e.stackTrace.take(10).join('\n')}")
    } finally {
        if (db != null) {
            db.close()
        }
    }
    
    return message;
}

class DatabaseManager {
    private Sql sql
    private boolean isConnected = false
    
    DatabaseManager(String hostPort, String database, String username, String password) {
        String jdbcUrl = "jdbc:postgresql://${hostPort}/${database}?sslmode=require"
        try {
            this.sql = Sql.newInstance(jdbcUrl, username, password, "org.postgresql.Driver")
            this.isConnected = true
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new RuntimeException("Failed to connect to database: ${e.message}", e)
        }
    }
    
    Sql getSql() {
        if (!isConnected) {
            throw new IllegalStateException("Database connection is closed")
        }
        return sql
    }
    
    void close() {
        if (sql != null && isConnected) {
            sql.close()
            isConnected = false
        }
    }
}

Result

=== Creating Table ===
Table 'test_table' created successfully

=== Inserting Row ===
Inserted row: ID=3, Name=Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:04, Created=2025-12-24 04:52:04.248478

=== Selecting All Rows ===
Found 3 row(s):
  ID: 3 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:04 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:52:04.248478
  ID: 2 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:02 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:52:02.147281
  ID: 1 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:51:55 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:51:55.597395

 

This script will perhaps help SAP CI developers understand how certain things work in SAP CI at the database level.

Again I am not encouraging anyone to modify the postgree db of SAP CI and this is only here for the curious bunch.

entry.title: Re: Implementing S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Great summary, Manuel 👍
Very practical recommendations, especially around Fit‑to‑Standard, change management, release calendar awareness, and extensibility choices (in‑app vs BTP).
I also agree that early role definition and data migration are often underestimated in S/4HANA Cloud projects.
Thanks for sharing the useful links in one place—this is very helpful for anyone starting with S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

entry.title: Re: How can SAP Build and SAP Integration Suite support your journey to SAP S/4HANA Cloud?
entry.content: Great overview of how SAP Build and SAP Integration Suite support a clean core strategy during S/4HANA Cloud migration. The real customer examples clearly show the value of side‑by‑side extensibility and integration on BTP. Thanks for sharing these insights!

entry.title: Re: How to prepare your SAP S/4HANA Conversion Project.
entry.content: Great and very detailed overview of an SAP S/4HANA conversion project. The emphasis on readiness checks, sandbox iterations, and downtime planning is especially valuable for project managers. Thanks for sharing practical insights based on real project experience!

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2102 Release
entry.content: Great overview of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2102 release. The end-to-end highlights across Finance, Supply Chain, AI/ML, and SAP Activate clearly show how SAP continues to drive intelligent and scalable cloud ERP innovations. Thanks for sharing these valuable insights!

entry.title: Re: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Upgrade Faster – Major shifts in SAP Fiori implementation
entry.content: For a brownfield migration, SAP recommends moving from Standalone (Hub) FES to Embedded FES as part of the S/4HANA upgrade. Custom and standard Fiori apps should be re‑deployed to the embedded system (or BTP where applicable), and technical catalogs migrated using Launchpad App Manager. This approach reduces landscape complexity and aligns with SAP’s long‑term strategy.

entry.title: Re: SAP HCM Processes and Forms JAVA and Adobe no longer available in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content: Thank you for the detailed and practical explanation. This is very helpful for understanding the impact of removing Adobe-based HCM Processes & Forms in S/4HANA and the recommended migration path to Fiori/FPM forms. The step-by-step guidance and SAP Notes references make it especially useful for real project scenarios.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Extended Warehouse Management Private Edition 2023 FPS02– What’s New
entry.content: Great overview of the SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 EWM enhancements. The improvements in ASR streaming, production integration, and extensibility are especially valuable for reducing lead times and improving warehouse efficiency. Thanks for sharing these insights!

entry.title: Re: Data migration is quite slow
entry.content: This is not expected behavior for such a small and simple material dataset. Even with multiple plant extensions, 13 hours for ~5,000 materials indicates a performance or configuration issue. Common causes include background job bottlenecks, system resource constraints in the Q system, or validations/enhancements triggered during migration. Splitting files helps only as a workaround. I recommend raising an SAP incident under CA-GTF-MIG with migration logs so SAP can analyze the runtime and identify the exact performance bottleneck.

entry.title: Re: GROW with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, base: An Overview of the base edition bundle
entry.content: Thanks for the clear breakdown of the GROW with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition base entitlements. Very helpful to understand what’s included out of the box. It would be great to also see a concise comparison of Finance scope items between Base and Premium editions, especially from an adoption and licensing perspective.

entry.title: Re: Making the Right-Sized Move to SAP S/4HANA
entry.content: Great overview of making a right-sized move to SAP S/4HANA. The focus on data archiving and SAP ILM is very relevant, especially for reducing migration effort and long-term TCO. Thanks for highlighting the importance of managing data lifecycle and compliance early in the journey.

entry.title: Re: A method to estimate the effort of a transformation project (SAP S/4HANA) especially the Custom
entry.content: Great article, Norman. I really like the task-based and iterative approach to effort estimation, especially how it aligns with SAP Activate and avoids going down to object-level complexity. The integration of empirical data and Delphi method makes it very practical for real S/4HANA transformation projects. Thanks for sharing your research and insights.

entry.title: Re: Critical Success Factors for a Seamless SAP S/4HANA Transition
entry.content: Well summarized. The focus on data quality, standardization, and change management really reflects what makes S/4HANA projects successful in practice.

entry.title: Re: Changes in Sales & Distribution (SD) in SAP S/4HANA w.r.t ECC
entry.content: Very informative and well-structured overview of SD changes in S/4HANA compared to ECC. Thanks for clearly linking technical simplifications with business benefits.

entry.title: Re: The Final Countdown to SAP S/4HANA: Simplify Your Journey with SDT
entry.content: • “Thanks for the clear and practical overview.”

entry.title: Re: SAP Data Migration Solutions Available to Make a Smooth Move to SAP S/4HANA
entry.content: Great overview of the SAP S/4HANA transition options. The focus on Selective Data Transition as a balanced approach—especially for downtime reduction, data volume optimization, and phased rollouts—is very practical and helpful for customers planning complex migrations.

entry.title: Re: Reducing the DataBase Size of SAP ERP Systems Using Shell Copy Scenario
entry.content: Very insightful post explaining the Shell Copy scenario and its benefits for reducing database size and downtime. The practical explanation of how it differs from a traditional system copy makes it easy to understand its value for S/4HANA transitions. Thanks for sharing this useful approach.

entry.title: Re: 🚀☁️ Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud: A Business Transformation Journey
entry.content: Great overview of SAP HANA Cloud migration. The real-world scenarios and clear positioning with RISE/GROW with SAP make this a very practical and business-focused read.
